title: Seoul stocks inch up slightly on tech gains
text: Stocks closed slightly higher Tuesday as Samsung Electronics and other tech stocks gained, but sentiment remained fragile over renewed uncertainties regarding the U.S.-China trade talks. The Korean won fell against the dollar.The Kospi rose 0.77 points, or 0.04 percent, to close at 2,068.17. Trade volume was moderate at 457 million shares worth 4.07 trillion won ($3.43 billion).The local stock market opened lower on profit-taking, tracking a slight decline on Wall Street overnight.Investors also took to the sidelines ahead of the Bank of Korea’s policy meeting slated for Wednesday.Roh Dong-gil, an analyst at NH Investment & Securities, said doubts about the U.S.-China trade talks emerged over news reports that Beijing wants more negotiations before the two nations reach a written agreement.Samsung Electronics rose 0.2 percent to end at 50,100 won and SK Hynix, a global chipmaker, gained 0.87 percent to 81,200 won.Naver, the operator of the country’s main internet portal, shed 2.88 percent to 151,500 won.Hyundai Motor remained flat at 122,000 won, and its smaller affiliate Kia Motors dipped 0.61 percent to 40,550 won. Auto parts maker Hyundai Mobis rose 2.08 percent to 245,500 won.Pharmaceutical firms were mixed, with Celltrion gaining 0.55 percent to reach 183,500 won. Samsung BioLogics inched down 1.06 percent to 326,000 won. LG Chem shed 0.33 percent to reach 303,000 won. Hanmi Pharmaceutical rose 0.52 percent to 292,500 won.Financial stocks were mixed. Shinhan Financial, a major banking group, inched up 0.12 percent at 42,550 won and KB Financial fell 0.23 percent at 42,700 won.Telecom shares were mixed. SK Telecom gained 0.63 percent to 238,000 won, but KT dropped 0.19 percent at 26,950 won. Their smaller rival LG U+ closed 0.36 percent higher at 13,950 won.Refiners traded lower. SK Innovation moved down 2.96 percent to end at 164,000 won and S-Oil inched dropped 3.32 percent to end at 99,100 won.The local currency closed at 1,185.20 won against the dollar, up 0.3 won from the previous session’s close.The secondary Kosdaq gained 5.34 points, or 0.83 percent, to close at 646.80Bond prices were mixed. The yield on three-year bonds fell 0.4 basis points to 1.277 percent.BY KIM BYUNG-WOOK, YONHAP [kim.byungwook@joongang.co.kr]
